item.title: Something for the Weekend – 13/09/25
item.content:encoded:
It’s heckin’ windy and rainy out and about, so it’s a good weekend to have a cosy time inside playing nice and lovely video games. Definitely nothing spooky and horror-filled – it’s not October yet. Personally, I’ll be continuing with Everybody’s Golf, maybe the Donkey Kong DLC and I need to get back to Indiana Jones’ DLC as well.

In the News This Week

The Nintendo Direct for Mario’s 40th had a good few announcement and surprises for us.

  • Fire Emblem: Fortune’s Weave revealed for Nintendo Switch 2
  • Hades 2 gets its full launch for PC and Switch 1 & 2 in September
  • The Super Mario Galaxy Movie is set to release in April 2026
  • Dragon Quest VII Reimagined is out next year
  • Hyrule Warriors: Age of Imprisonment and Metroid Prime 4 have confirmed release dates
  • Virtual Boy is joining the Switch Online library, but you’ll need a stereoscopic accessory!
  • Nintendo wants $70 / £59 for the Super Mario Galaxy 1 & 2 remaster
  • Mario Tennis Fever swings onto Switch 2 in February
  • Yoshi and the Mysterious Book announced for Switch 2
  • Here are all the announcements from Acclaim’s showcase
  • Football Manager 26 releases on November 4th
  • Dambuster tease Dead Island 3, but where will the next outbreak be?

Games in Review & Featured Articles

We didn’t get Borderlands 4 code ahead of that game’s release, so put our focus elsewhere for this week’s reviews:

  • Sword of the Sea – PS5, PC – 10/10
  • Grit & Valor 1949 – PS5, XSX|S, NSW, PC, Quest, PSVR 2 – 7/10
  • Hell Clock – PC – 6/10
  • Peglin – PS5, XSX|S, PS4, XBO, NSW, PC – 6/10
  • Lost Soul Aside – PS5, PC – 5/10

Dom also turned in a hardware review for the Noble Fokus Amadeus true wireless earbuds.

I then delivered a batch of previews, going hands on with Little Nightmares 3, and speaking to Producer Coralie Feniello about the shift to co-op and more. As well as this, I had an extended hands on time with Digimon Story: Time Stranger, and got to see SponeBob SquarePants: Titans of the Tide in action.

Rounding out the week, What We Played featured Everybody’s Golf, Metal Gear Solid Delta & Lost Soul Aside.

Trailer Park

Resident Evil Requiem coming to Switch 2, along with Resident Evil Biohazard and Village

Destiny 2’s Star Wars inspired Renegades expansion launches December 2nd

Pokémon Pokopia feels a bit Animal Crossing & Stardew-y

That’s the round up for this week, stay out of the stormy weather this weekend, and we’ll catch you back here on Monday!

item.title: Nintendo wants $70 / £59 for the Super Mario Galaxy 1 & 2 remaster
item.content:encoded:
Tying in with The Super Mario Galaxy Movie, Nintendo is remastering Super Mario Galaxy and Super Mario Galaxy 2 for Nintendo Switch and Switch 2, launching on 2nd October. It will cost you a pretty penny to get their collection of Nintendo Wii titles, though, with the two game bundle costing $70 / £59, or being available individually for $40 / £34 apiece.

The remasters promise:

  • Upgraded visuals for both games.
  • Assist Mode to help with your adventure, which can be turned on and off whenever you like. It lets you play with more health, heal just by standing still and return to solid ground if you fall into space.
  • An additional chapter of Rosalina’s picture book in Super Mario Galaxy, and an entirely new picture book in Super Mario Galaxy 2.
  • Listen to the soundtrack of each game from the main menu with 154 tracks in total.

Switch 2 support is being included for free, letting both games be played at 4K output in TV mode and 1080p on the built-in screen.

While it’s great to have these two games on Switch – they’re still regarded as two of the best platformers of all time – and the upgrades are nice, the price tag stings. Super Mario Galaxy and its sequel launched in 2007 and 2010 respectively, with the first getting much more love and attention with re-releases since then. In 2015 both games were released on the Wii U eShop in unenhanced form and with a discount $20 price point. A few years later, the first game was then included in the Super Mario 3D All-Stars collection for Mario’s 35th anniversary alongside Mario 64 and Super Mario Sunshine. This time-limited collection wrapped the three games up in emulation layers to enhance visuals and UI, before being pulled from sale just six months later.

Further Reading: Super Mario Galaxy 2 – A Modern Masterpiece

This duology remaster does go further than 3D All-Stars with Switch 2 support and some gameplay additions, and it does allow you to avoid double-dipping by just buying Galaxy 2, but it’s still an immediate point of controversy to have this sticker price.

Source: Nintendo
